awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A Novel Method for Atmospheric Correction of Earth Observation Satellite Data
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to improve satellite-based agricultural imaging to allow monitoring and managing of broad regions for enhanced sustainability and food security.  The proposed algorithms address noise in satellite data that is caused by the atmosphere.  The method can be used for many types of satellites, providing advantages in efforts to reduce weight and space to control launch cost.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to address a major issue in modern remote sensing, atmospherically induced noise in the data. EOS systems look through the atmosphere that distorts spectral relationships of reflectance (ratio of EOS-measured reflected light to the sunlight that would be received were there no atmosphere). The variable atmosphere distorts the data variably so must be corrected to accurately interpret highly useful measures such as agricultural production/yield, photosynthesis, plant water use, plant disease/insect infestations, etc., rendering EOS data unreliable unless corrected. The technical tasks are to: (1) study European Space Agency Sentinel 2 EOS data, (2) migrate the method to NASA/USGS Landsat 8, (3) adapt the method for calibration of the several decades-long Landsat Multispectral Scanner record that cannot otherwise be corrected to surface reflectance, (4) develop a calibration tool for multiple commercial EOS, and (5) develop a fully integrated software system.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Optical satellite remote sensing is rapidly expanding in use and importance. Daily satellite recon images are now viewed in the news by billions each day. Such satellites are being miniaturized and fielded in flocks so that multiple visits now occur over the entire Earth each day. While imagery collection has greatly accelerated, the science for removing atmospheric effects from the imagery have severely lagged. Such atmospheric effects manifest as haze in images that can range from barely visible to completely occlusion of the ground signal. These effects must be removed for reliable analysis and clear viewing.

 The greatest value of multiple visits per day is real-time recon. Image correction must also be near real-time: in many situations stale recon is useless. Because of the number of images, all such analyses must occur under automation using accurately corrected data that are analysis ready.

 This project has successfully developed ?Closed-form Method for Atmospheric Correction? (CMAC), a superior alternative to existing methods for atmospheric correction of visible and near infrared imagery (VNIR); the data most often collected by imaging satellites. Compared to existing methods, CMAC is accurate over a greatly increased range of atmospheric effects (~3x) in near real-time. In addition, CMAC uniquely can correct imagery over any environment, including deserts and water bodies.

 Existing methods attempt to correct atmospheric effects through a theoretic basis following the known physics of light. Atmospheric effects on images derive mainly from suspended aerosol particles and water vapor that are highly variable in time and space as air masses flow past. Such effects are complex and while some individual math relationships can be known, interactive effects among them are not. Hence, data insufficiency is an inherent problem for a theoretic solution that is accommodated iterative fitting to approximate solutions to estimate surface reflectance. That solution works well only for images that are already clear or very nearly so.

CMAC is a new paradigm because it reverses atmospheric effects using only the data from the image to be corrected and processing these data using relationships that were derived through study of many images taken under a wide variety of atmospheric effects. CMAC is a three-step process first requiring calibration of each new orbiting satellite to use the method: this Part 0 is pre-operational. Following calibration, CMAC can convert top-of-atmosphere (TOA) data to surface reflectance from then on. Part 1 maps the atmospheric degradation across the image that, in Part 2, is then reversed to deliver an estimate of surface reflectance for each pixel. Part 1 output is atmospheric effect grayscale ? the brighter the response, the greater the correction. The calibration derived in Part 0 is applied in Part 2 to translate the grayscale into input parameters that reverse the mapped atmospheric effects with the only other input being bandwise TOA pixel values.

 CMAC?s closed-form solution reverses atmospheric effects. It was discovered through observation of atmospheric effects upon the statistical distribution of pixels. The methods and calibrations were derived using Sentinel2 satellite data as the testbed and are applicable to all other satellites and band combinations through relatively minor adjustment.

 Observation of the data distributions for TOA versus surface reflectance disclosed that atmospheric effects cause dark reflectance to increase (backscatter) and bright reflectance to decrease (attenuation). At a point in-between, scatter and attenuation self-balance where TOA and surface reflectances remain the same. This response was a clue that the changes in reflectance form a continuum.

 CMAC functionality is significantly greater than existing methods: CMAC requires about <1/10 the processing time and delivers verified accuracy over a far higher magnitude of atmospheric effects in near real-time. Uniquely, CMAC uses only scene statistics for all calculations. Existing methods require ancillary data from other satellites to assess atmospheric effects; but supply three orders of magnitude lower granularity after waiting days to receive the data.  

 CMAC is now a minimum viable product, especially for precision agriculture applications and is being groomed for defense applications. At partial list of additional utility that will be developed is :

  • Far off-nadir viewing for pointable satellites that can capture multiple views daily of hotspots from various angles.
  • CMAC residence in-satellite so images collected by push broom scanner can be corrected and transmitted during collection. This can be achieved by a several-seconds lag for the software to correct and output the data. This capability responds to DoD need for edge computation/low latency for warfighter support.
  • Extremely high solar zenith angle correction: polar applications.
  • Rapid automated calibration methods for new satellites and repeatable QA/QC: automated software can manage hundreds of satellites on the fly.
  • Application to hyperspectral satellites.
  • Correction for the effect of extreme levels of atmospheric water vapor content (occurs seasonally in portions of an equatorial belt).
